note: This handbook is a simple backend reference for UI use. Language is plain English for general users; values are indicative — agencies use different averaging periods and thresholds. OpenWeather AQI uses category 1..5 (a category, not a numerical AQI index). Category meanings are given in the `AQI` entry.

AQI.what_it_is: A simple category (1 to 5) that summarizes overall air quality using several pollutants. Note: this is a category number, not a raw numerical AQI index. Higher category means worse air quality.
health_risks: Higher categories mean higher chance of breathing trouble, coughing, or worsening of asthma and heart conditions.
Short outdoor exposure is usually safe at low categories; higher categories increase risk for sensitive people.
vulnerable_groups: People with asthma or lung disease

guideline_levels.label: 1 (Good)
guideline_levels.note: Air quality is considered good for most people.

guideline_levels.label: 2 (Fair / Moderate)
guideline_levels.note: Some sensitive people may experience mild symptoms; consider light activity indoors if you are sensitive.

guideline_levels.label: 3 (Poor / Unhealthy for sensitive groups)
guideline_levels.note: Sensitive people should reduce prolonged or heavy outdoor exertion.

guideline_levels.label: 4 (Very Poor / Unhealthy)
guideline_levels.note: Reduce outdoor activity; vulnerable groups should avoid exertion.

guideline_levels.label: 5 (Severe / Hazardous)
guideline_levels.note: Everyone should avoid prolonged outdoor exposure; follow local health advice.

what_to_do: Check the category before planning long outdoor activities.
Sensitive people should reduce outdoor exercise starting at category 2–3.
Keep windows closed during high categories and use indoor air filtration if available.
Avoid strenuous outdoor sports at category 3 or higher; prefer light indoor activity.

PM2.5.what_it_is: Very small particles (2.5 micrometres or smaller) that can travel deep into the lungs and sometimes into the bloodstream.
health_risks: Irritation of the airways, coughing and shortness of breath
Worsening of asthma and chronic lung disease
Increased risk for heart problems with long or repeated exposure

guideline_levels.label: Unhealthy
guideline_levels.note: Reduce outdoor exertion; vulnerable groups should limit time outside.

guideline_levels.label: Hazardous
guideline_levels.note: Avoid outdoor activities; use filtration indoors if possible.

what_to_do: Reduce or reschedule outdoor exercise when PM2.5 is elevated.
Use an N95/FFP2 respirator when spending time outdoors in high-pollution situations.
Keep windows closed and use indoor air cleaners or central filtration when available.

PM10.what_it_is: Larger airborne particles (up to 10 micrometres) that can irritate the nose and throat and be breathed into the upper lungs.
health_risks: Aggravation of asthma and breathing problems for sensitive people

guideline_levels.label: Unhealthy
guideline_levels.note: Limit outdoor activity for vulnerable people.

what_to_do: Avoid heavy outdoor exertion during dust events.
Use masks in dusty conditions if you are sensitive.
Keep indoor spaces dust-free and use filtration where possible.

O3.what_it_is: A reactive gas that at ground level is created by reactions of other pollutants in sunlight. It can irritate the lungs and reduce lung function.
typical_sources: Forms in sunlight from traffic and industrial emissions (secondary pollutant)
health_risks: Coughing, chest tightness, shortness of breath
Worse symptoms during exercise or for people with asthma

guideline_levels.label: Low
guideline_levels.note: Low immediate health risk for most people.

guideline_levels.label: Moderate/High
guideline_levels.value: Elevated on sunny days with lots of traffic; follow local alerts
guideline_levels.note: Sensitive people should reduce outdoor exercise.

what_to_do: Avoid intense outdoor exercise on hot, sunny days when ozone rises.
Children and people with asthma should limit outdoor play or sports during high-ozone alerts.
Follow local air-quality advisories for specific guidance.

NO2.what_it_is: A gas produced mainly by burning fuels. Short-term exposure irritates the airways and can make breathing harder.
health_risks: Increased risk of respiratory infections and worsening of asthma

guideline_levels.label: Elevated
guideline_levels.value: Near busy roads or during heavy traffic; sensitive people may be affected

what_to_do: Avoid standing close to busy traffic for long periods.
Choose less-polluted routes for walking or cycling if possible.
People with asthma should keep rescue medication available and avoid intense outdoor exertion in traffic-polluted areas.

SO2.what_it_is: A gas produced by burning sulfur-containing fuels and by some industrial processes. High short-term levels can cause breathing problems.
health_risks: Shortness of breath and wheezing, especially for people with asthma
Can trigger bronchospasm in sensitive people

guideline_levels.label: Elevated
guideline_levels.value: During industrial events or heavy combustion; sensitive people may be affected

what_to_do: Follow local advisories during industrial releases or power-plant events.
People with respiratory disease should avoid outdoor exertion when SO2 is reported high.

CO.what_it_is: A colorless gas formed by incomplete burning of carbon fuels. Very high levels can prevent oxygen carrying in the blood.
typical_sources: Household heating and cooking with poor ventilation
health_risks: Headache, dizziness, and at very high levels loss of consciousness; chronic low-level exposure can stress the heart in people with disease

guideline_levels.label: Elevated
guideline_levels.value: Near heavy traffic or in poorly ventilated indoor combustion settings

what_to_do: Avoid sitting with car engines idling in closed spaces.
Ensure good ventilation when using gas heaters or stoves and service combustion appliances regularly.
People with heart disease should avoid areas with heavy traffic smog.
